title: 109_hr1317
content: The Act may be cited as the "Federal Employee Protection of Disclosures Act" and clarifies the disclosures covered. Section 2302(b)(8) of title 5, United States Code is amended to broaden the scope of protected disclosures by employees or applicants without restrictions on time, place, form, motive, context, or prior disclosure. The scope of protected disclosures by employees or applicants is broadened without restrictions on time, place, form, motive, context, or prior disclosure. The amendment allows for disclosure of information believed to be evidence of any violation (other than a violation of this section). SEC. 3. COVERED DISCLOSURES amends Section 2302(a)(2) of title 5, United States Code to define 'disclosure' as a communication that evidences violations of laws, rules, regulations, mismanagement, waste of funds, abuse of authority, or danger to public health or safety. Section 2302(b) of title 5, United States Code is amended to allow the rebuttal of presumptions related to employee duties. It also specifies criteria for determining if an employee reasonably believes they have disclosed violations of law, mismanagement, waste of funds, abuse of authority, or danger to public health or safety. SEC. 5. NONDISCLOSURE POLICIES, FORMS, AND AGREEMENTS. The text chunk discusses amendments to personnel actions and prohibited personnel practices related to the implementation or enforcement of nondisclosure policies, forms, or agreements. The provisions outlined do not override employee obligations under various laws and regulations, including Executive Order No. 12958, statutes governing disclosures to Congress and military members, and laws protecting against disclosures compromising national security. The agreement incorporates definitions, requirements, obligations, rights, sanctions, and liabilities from Executive Order No. 12958 and the Activities Control Act of 1950. It prohibits conducting investigations of employees or applicants based on protected activities. SEC. 6. EXCLUSION OF AGENCIES BY THE PRESIDENT. Amends Section 2302(a)(2)(C) of title 5, United States Code, to exclude certain agencies as determined by the President. SEC. 7. DISCIPLINARY ACTION. Section 1215(a)(3) of title 5, United States Code, is amended to allow the Merit Systems Protection Board to impose disciplinary actions such as removal, reduction in grade, debarment, suspension, or reprimand, as well as civil penalties up to $1,000 for prohibited personnel practices. The Board must impose disciplinary action if the protected activity was the primary motivating factor, unless the employee proves otherwise. The Merit Systems Protection Board can impose disciplinary actions for prohibited personnel practices, including removal, reduction in grade, debarment, suspension, or reprimand, as well as civil penalties up to $1,000. The employee must prove that the protected activity was not the primary motivating factor for the personnel action. Government Accountability Office to study security clearance revocations post-1996 for personnel filing claims under title 5, chapter 12. Report due by June 30, 2006 to House and Senate committees. Effective date of the Act is 30 days after enactment.
